pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 193, 304, 209]]<|/det|>
# FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 156, 231]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 259, 440, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF10)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 320, 390, 338]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 367, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 384, 327, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 447, 285, 463]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 463, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
The use of a calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 510, 907, 540]]<|/det|>
Results obtained solely from a graphic calculator, without supporting working or reasoning, will not receive credit.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 540, 606, 556]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 570, 606, 586]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 586, 757, 602]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 94, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Express \(\frac{1}{r(r + 1)(r - 1)}\) in partial fractions. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 116, 160, 134]]<|/det|>
<label>Find</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 134, 579, 179]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 2}^{n}\frac{1}{r(r + 1)(r - 1)}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 144, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 193, 262, 212]]<|/det|>
State the value of

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 212, 579, 256]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 2}^{\infty}\frac{1}{r(r + 1)(r - 1)}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 227, 920, 246]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 304, 94, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 291, 536, 343]]<|/det|>
Show that the matrix \(\begin{array}{r}\left( \begin{array}{ll}1 & 4 & 2\\ 3 & 0 & -2\\ 3 & -3 & -4 \end{array} \right) \end{array}\) has no inverse.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 304, 920, 323]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 352, 359, 371]]<|/det|>
Solve the system of equations

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 370, 567, 425]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{array}{c}x + 4y + 2z = 0,\\ 3x - 2z = 4,\\ 3x - 3y - 4z = 5. \end{array}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 409, 920, 428]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 457, 96, 476]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 456, 537, 477]]<|/det|>
Find the general solution of the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 484, 604, 518]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}y}{\mathrm{dx}^{2}} +2\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} +4y = 4x^{2} + 8.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 490, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 551, 96, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 551, 390, 570]]<|/det|>
A curve has parametric equations

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 577, 712, 597]]<|/det|>
\[x = 2\theta -\sin 2\theta ,\quad y = 1 - \cos 2\theta ,\quad \mathrm{for} -3\pi \leqslant \theta \leqslant 3\pi .\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 604, 203, 622]]<|/det|>
Show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 622, 546, 653]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = \cot \theta ,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 655, 549, 675]]<|/det|>
except for certain values of \(\theta\), which should be stated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 657, 920, 675]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 688, 401, 724]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}y}{\mathrm{dx}^{2}}\) when \(\theta = \frac{1}{4}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 696, 920, 715]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 750, 96, 768]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 750, 228, 768]]<|/det|>
The equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 769, 601, 789]]<|/det|>
\[8x^{3} + 36x^{2} + kx - 21 = 0,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 794, 920, 829]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant, has roots \(a - d\), \(a\), \(a + d\). Find the numerical values of the roots and determine the value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 812, 920, 831]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 97, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 880, 103]]<|/det|>
[In this question you may use, without proof, the formula \(\int \sec x \mathrm{d}x = \ln (\sec x + \tan x) + \mathrm{const.}]\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 144, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 116, 846, 136]]<|/det|>
Let \(y = \sec x\). Find the mean value of \(y\) with respect to \(x\) over the interval \(\frac{1}{6}\pi \leqslant x \leqslant \frac{1}{3}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 117, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 152, 146, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 151, 814, 170]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = - \ln (\cos x)\), for \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant \frac{1}{3}\pi\). Find the arc length of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 197, 97, 216]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 197, 326, 216]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 218, 571, 254]]<|/det|>
\[y = \frac{2x^{2} + 5x - 1}{x + 2}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 262, 460, 282]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the asymptotes of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 263, 920, 282]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 293, 343, 322]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} > 2\) at all points on \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 298, 920, 317]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 201, 353]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 336, 920, 354]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 381, 96, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 381, 445, 400]]<|/det|>
The points \(A, B, C\) have position vectors

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 406, 690, 427]]<|/det|>
\[4\mathbf{i} + 5\mathbf{j} + 6\mathbf{k},\qquad 5\mathbf{i} + 7\mathbf{j} + 8\mathbf{k},\qquad 2\mathbf{i} + 6\mathbf{j} + 4\mathbf{k},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 433, 767, 453]]<|/det|>
respectively, relative to the origin \(O\). Find a cartesian equation of the plane \(ABC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 434, 920, 453]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 465, 920, 500]]<|/det|>
The point \(D\) has position vector \(6\mathbf{i} + 3\mathbf{j} + 6\mathbf{k}\). Find the coordinates of \(E\), the point of intersection of the line \(OD\) with the plane \(ABC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 483, 920, 502]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 511, 611, 532]]<|/det|>
Find the acute angle between the line \(ED\) and the plane \(ABC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 512, 920, 530]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 558, 96, 576]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 558, 648, 577]]<|/det|>
Prove by mathematical induction that, for every positive integer \(n\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[356, 584, 641, 603]]<|/det|>
\[(\cos \theta + \mathrm{i}\sin \theta)^{n} = \cos n\theta +\mathrm{i}\sin n\theta .\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 584, 920, 603]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 621, 920, 657]]<|/det|>
Express \(\sin^{5}\theta\) in the form \(p \sin 5\theta + q \sin 3\theta + r \sin \theta\), where \(p\), \(q\) and \(r\) are rational numbers to be determined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 640, 920, 658]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 691, 104, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 685, 923, 728]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has polar equation \(r = 2 \sin \theta (1 - \cos \theta)\), for \(0 \leqslant \theta \leqslant \pi\). Find \(\frac{\mathrm{d}r}{\mathrm{d}\theta}\) and hence find the polar coordinates of the point of \(C\) that is furthest from the pole.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 711, 920, 730]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 742, 201, 759]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 742, 920, 759]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 772, 551, 791]]<|/det|>
Find the exact area of the sector from \(\theta = 0\) to \(\theta = \frac{1}{4}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 772, 920, 791]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 527, 92]]<|/det|>
Answer only **one** of the following two alternatives.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 112, 201, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>EITHER</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 139, 880, 179]]<|/det|>
Let \(I_{n} = \int_{0}^{1}(1 + x^{2})^{n}\mathrm{d}x.\) Show that, for all integers \(n,\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 183, 598, 203]]<|/det|>
\[(2n + 1)I_n = 2nI_{n - 1} + 2^n.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 183, 920, 202]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 221, 356, 240]]<|/det|>
Evaluate \(I_{0}\) and hence find \(I_{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 221, 920, 240]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 253, 348, 273]]<|/det|>
Given that \(I_{-1} = \frac{1}{4}\pi\), find \(I_{-3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 254, 920, 273]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 293, 153, 311]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 324, 920, 358]]<|/det|>
The vector \(\mathbf{e}\) is an eigenvector of each of the \(3 \times 3\) matrices \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\), with corresponding eigenvalues \(\lambda\) and \(\mu\) respectively. Justifying your answer, state an eigenvalue of \(\mathbf{A} + \mathbf{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 343, 920, 361]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 370, 288, 388]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{A}\), where

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 388, 586, 439]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 & -1 & -6 \\ 1 & 0 & -2 \\ 3 & -1 & -3 \end{pmatrix},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 448, 695, 496]]<|/det|>
has eigenvectors \(\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}\). Find the corresponding eigenvalues.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 460, 920, 479]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 504, 288, 523]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{B}\), where

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 522, 586, 574]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{B} = \begin{pmatrix} 8 & -2 & -8 \\ 2 & 0 & -4 \\ 4 & -2 & -4 \end{pmatrix},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 580, 920, 625]]<|/det|>
also has eigenvectors \(\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}\), for which \(-2, 2, 4\), respectively, are corresponding eigenvalues. The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) is given by \(\mathbf{M} = \mathbf{A} + \mathbf{B} - 5\mathbf{I}\), where \(\mathbf{I}\) is the \(3 \times 3\) identity matrix.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 636, 920, 664]]<|/det|>
State the eigenvalues of \(\mathbf{M}\). [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 673, 670, 692]]<|/det|>
Find matrices \(\mathbf{R}\) and \(\mathbf{S}\) and a diagonal matrix \(\mathbf{D}\) such that \(\mathbf{M}^{5} = \mathbf{R}\mathbf{D}\mathbf{S}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 673, 920, 692]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 698, 683, 717]]<|/det|>
[You should show clearly all the elements of the matrices \(\mathbf{R}, \mathbf{S}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\).]
